captions.text:
You know what they say, if you&#39;re gonna get
kicked in the balls, might as well get kicked
in the balls twice so they stay symmetrical.

And that&#39;s why it&#39;s time for the first indie
double bill of the year.

Gratifyingly for my love of connecting themes,
both games are named after a word that means
&quot;grey.&quot;

Not only that, but they&#39;re both words that
mean &quot;grey&quot; that you might use if you&#39;re a
pretentious twat.
Or French.
For all the difference that makes.
So let&#39;s start with Gris.
Gris is a platformer.

There, I&#39;ve just described the game about
nine times more efficiently than the blurb

on Gris&#39; Steam page, which describes it as
&quot;a serene and evocative experience about pain

and an atmospheric journey through sorrow&quot;
it&#39;s a fucking platformer, alright?

You remember that game FAR: Lone Sails, which
would more accurately have been titled CAR:
With Sails?

Nice little idea about maintaining a complex
vehicle on a long journey, but went for a

slightly inconsistent bleak melancholy atmosphere
because, as I said at the time, it had a bad
case of indie game-itis?

Well, Gris is patient fucking zero for indie
game-itis.
Always the same, these oscar bait games.

Just make an atmospheric platformer where
the main character is implied to be sad and
watch the Best Art Direction prizes roll in.

Gris is about a stick figure in a dress with
a girl&#39;s head trying to cheer up their giant

statue friend, but when that doesn&#39;t seem
to be going well she must explore a strange

empty world to repopulate it with colours,
while being threatened by an ever encroaching

amorphous blackness, also known as Baby&#39;s
First Metaphor.

The flat out stated intention is that this
is all a metaphor for overcoming sadness,
which invites further analysis.

Maybe the one ability where you make yourself
very heavy and do a ground pound is a metaphor

for eating a bunch of cakes to cheer yourself
up.

In all seriousness now, Gris is of course
a very beautiful game with haunting arty watercolour-style

backgrounds, a very good soundtrack and what
looks like hand drawn animation as smooth

as a virginal college boy&#39;s hand moving across
a frustrated cougar&#39;s thigh.

But then actual control was given to me and
I&#39;d push right, only for the character&#39;s beautifully

animated walk cycle to glide across the ground
like I&#39;m dragging an icon across a Windows
desktop.

And that sums up my issue with this very artistic
and emotional experience - that its eyes keep

glazing over whenever it has to address the
whole video game thing.

As I said, it&#39;s a platformer, and sort of
a Metroidvania because you unlock new movement

abilities as you go, but there&#39;s not much
point in going back to old areas unless you&#39;re
having trouble sleeping.

The level design kinda herds you through the
set pieces and there isn&#39;t much challenge.

At one pseudo action sequence where my character
was fleeing with the blackness snapping at

her heels, I experimentally put down the controller
and she successfully fled the blackness anyway.

Gris, do you really need me here or would
you rather just very artfully wibble away
to yourself while I pop out and run some errands?

I know this was the intention, let&#39;s go back
to that Steam blurb: &quot;GRIS is a serene experience
free of danger, frustration or death.&quot;

Listen here, clever tits: Locking myself in
a fucking bathroom with a paper bag on my

head would also be a serene experience free
of danger and adversity, but I wouldn&#39;t base
a game around it.

You indie emotional experiences and walking
simulators need to stop being so fucking sniffy
about gameplay.

Challenge is the tool by which video games
pace themselves and direct the player&#39;s attention,
and frankly I found Gris to be very boring.

Yes, a good story can be challenging in its
own way, but what&#39;s the story here?
Sad person wants to be less sad?
Not exactly American History X, is it.

So our second game whose title means &quot;Grey&quot;
is Ashen, which initially caught my interest

because at time of writing it&#39;s exclusive
to the Epic Games digital store.
Yeah, hope you&#39;re paying attention, Steam.

&#39;Cos plucky little underdog massive games
company Epic and its twelve or thirteen games

most of which Steam already has are gearing
up to TAKE YOU ON.

Well, it&#39;s early days yet, we might all be
enslaved in the Epic Megacorporation bitcoin

mines by next year, let&#39;s not tempt fate like
I did with the President Trump joke.
Ashen is a Dark Souls clone.

Again, I&#39;ve just been about nine times more
informative than its own store page was.

It&#39;s not even trying to hide the Dark Souls
influence, it&#39;s a high-difficulty action RPG

set in a dying world and the opening cinematic
is essentially a creation myth.

Although instead of an epic battle between
gods and dragons, you get a bird who sits
on a tree branch for a bit then falls off.

Which rather sets the tone for Ashen, and
that tone is grey.

Wow, both the games called grey turned out
to be boring.

It&#39;s almost like the colour grey has certain
associations attached.

What probably doesn&#39;t help is Ashen&#39;s distinctive
art style that makes it look like Dark Souls

the Playmobil Set, where every character is
a faceless plastic dolly running around a

landscape that someone with far too much time
on their hands made out of papier mache for
their Warhammer meetups.

And the gameplay is also the Playmobil version
of Dark Souls.
They give you a map, for a start.

Christ, why not give us fucking bunny slippers
while you&#39;re at it.

Dark Souls is about exploration, sticking
objective markers all over it is like publishing
a crossword with half the answers filled in.

Honestly though I can&#39;t complain, because
the NPC questgivers would only talk at me

in flowery Shakespearean monologues so I needed
the objectives to inform me of what the fuck
they actually wanted me to do.

The plot of Ashen is that you&#39;re exploring
the embers of the world to find NPC specialists

who can come help develop your home base at
Firelink Shrine, I mean, Majula, I mean, Vagrant&#39;s

Rest, and they give you sidequests to do alongside
your main quest to... you know, it was probably

mentioned at some point but then the combat
annoyed me too much and all I can remember
is my eyes filling up with blood.

As far as I can tell the main quest line was
&quot;keep advancing along a linear string of areas
so that you can do sidequests in them.&quot;
But that doesn&#39;t matter.

I&#39;d like to address now Ashen&#39;s most significant
feature: the multiplayer.

I&#39;d like to, but sadly I have no fucking clue
if I participated in it or not.

How it works is, you have an NPC support character
most of the time as you explore, and if another

player happens to be around pursuing the same
quest then they seamlessly take over your
support character.

Consequently a lot of the game is designed
around co-op - Dark Souls combat is best suited

to one-on-one fighting but the enemy almost
exclusively ambushes in groups - and support
is vital.

But either I never ran into another player
or the game had assessed my combat skill and

decided to exclusively matchmake me with the
severely mentally disabled.

I wouldn&#39;t mind an NPC that just stood still
and drew aggro while playing with their belly

buttons, but they&#39;re just competent enough
that you start relying on them, until you

wade confidently into a battle and glance
back to see them a hundred yards behind taking
undue interest in a shelf bracket.

I gave up on Ashen altogether after my seventeenth
failed attempt to get through a long, boring

dungeon trying to keep my support character
alive, only to watch them thrust a bit too
eagerly and plop off the walkway yet again.

It&#39;d be a good scam, wouldn&#39;t it, claiming
that we&#39;re playing co-op with uncommunicative
humans indistinguishable from NPCs.

It&#39;d be like an inverse of the Dumbo&#39;s magic
feather trick.

&quot;Maybe I could&#39;ve beaten that dungeon if the
other guy hadn&#39;t been such a fuckup.&quot;
&quot;Ha ha, don&#39;t you see?
There was no other guy!
The fuckup was in you all along!&quot;
